html_description:

  • How you can prepare your systems in case of an attack, including conducting audits and putting effective back up systems in place
  • How to protect your business against an attack
  • How to detect an attack so you can deal with it as soon as possible
  • How to respond to an attack – what are the key steps you need to take?
  • How to recover any documents or files lost or damaged
  • Reviewing cyber-attacks after they happen in order to establish what happened and what can be improved to ensure the same thing doesn’t happen again

This event is aimed at owners of small businesses, with no in-house IT support, IT managers & directors of larger businesses and organisations where the IT department does not have in-house cybersecurity expertise.

name: Better Environment Better Business – The Importance of Public Realm and Heritage
html_description:
Come and join us for cream tea at the Grade II* listed Bosworth Hall Hotel built in C1680 and find out why heritage and public realm is important to the economic health of towns and villages! This free business event will give you the opportunity to hear from experts on the public realm and key heritage tourism initiatives for the local area.  Local businesses are a crucial part of our communities bringing variation and vitality to our town centres and high streets, keeping money circulating in local economies and maintaining a sense of community. The quality of the public realm in which they operate can influence the numbers of people willing to visit and spend locally. A main ingredient for successful town centres is high quality public realm, which helps to create the conditions necessary to attract and retain investment – and can significantly increase the value of property in an area.

Over a third of all visits to attractions in England are to heritage and historic sites, this event will showcase what Hinckley and Bosworth is doing to help grab a share of this lucrative market. Hear an update on The Bosworth 1485 Sculpture Trail project which will comprise of a series of six significant works of art. The Trail will create an important new cultural and tourism destination for local people and visitors, increasing direct economic benefit to the area of at least £1million per annum,18 jobs, and 20,000 tourists, plus complement and bring trade to Bosworth Battlefield, the surrounding areas and Leicester attractions.

The event will also launch the new rural heritage trail which includes a blue and green plaque trail for the borough and highlights key historic areas of interest. An opportunity for further networking with other local businesses will follow.

This event will be of interest to local businesses, landowners and investors in market towns who want to find out how they can benefit from local investment in public realm. Heritage and tourism groups will also find this event useful as it will provide an opportunity to learn about the latest initiatives to boost heritage tourism in the Borough and how you can become involved.

Attendees will gain an understanding of the activity that is taking place locally to boost economic activity with details on both potential improvements to the public realm and how we are using heritage to promote the Borough as a destination to visit.

name: Employing Ex-Offenders to Drive Your Business Forward
html_description:
Do you struggle to recruit people with the right skills for your business?

With employment at an all-time high in Leicester, and businesses growing, where is the new workforce going to come from?

Born from a working group including the Police and Crime Commissioners Office, Leicester City Council and the Department for Work and Pensions, this event will look at the benefits and social value of employing ex-offenders. It will also include the launch of a new website and charter dedicated to the promotion of ex-offenders into employment.

The event is aimed at employers who are interested in revitalising their recruitment strategy and finding out how recruitment of this disadvantaged cohort could benefit and drive their business forward. Some of the benefits of employing ex-offenders include:

  • Access to an untapped resource of skilled and committed employees
  • Grant opportunity of £3500
  • Excellent CSR opportunity, providing employment for individuals who often find it difficult to rehabilitate and get back into the workplace. Employing ex-offenders also helps to keep society safer by contributing towards a reduction in re-offending rates
  • Enhance your recruitment strategy

It is hoped that attendees and district councils will also consider signing up to a new charter, which will include ‘ban the box’, pledging time for employability advice in prisons and a commitment to providing vacancies that are open to ex-offenders to apply for.

The agenda will include presentations about the benefits and ways to get involved with this initiative, speed-networking and presentations from ex-offenders who have been successfully rehabilitated into the workplace.

name: How to Resolve Disputes Quickly and Without Spending a Fortune
html_description:
Many businesses are likely to encounter conflict and disputes at some point, whether that’s with suppliers or customers. Disputes can occur for a variety of reasons, common disputes include landlord and tenant issues, an issue with a contract or a business not delivering as promised. Resolving disputes can be stressful, time consuming, extremely costly and ultimately take your focus away from your business.

Commercial mediation is a great alternative to the usual litigation route and allows disputes between businesses or between businesses and their customers to be solved quickly and cost-effectively, without the need for court proceedings. This event, delivered by commercial mediator Tim Bennett, will explore the benefits of mediation and how the mediation process works.

The event is aimed at business owners and managers. Any business can be subject to a dispute. Knowing how to resolve these disputes quickly is the key to ensuring they don't impact the business and costs don't escalate.

The event is aimed at businesses and other organisations who would like to process personal data in innovative ways.

name: Preparing for China's E-Commerce Market
html_description:
The Chinese e-commerce market is the world’s largest global e-commerce market, and by sales value, is larger than all other global e-commerce markets combined. It is still growing at a tremendous rate - 23.9% (year-on-year 2018 vs 2017), and now accounts for 23% of the total retail sales in the market. The total retail market in China is expected to be larger than the US for the first time ever in 2019.

For any British business selling consumer products, who are serious about expanding into the world’s largest consumer market, understanding the structure and requirements for entry onto Chinese e-commerce is vital.

At the same time, the Chinese e-commerce environment is very different to other economies. The barriers to entry remain high, and the language, culture, legal environment and buying habits all require an approach tailored to China to succeed.

To help British businesses take advantage of the opportunities, The China-Britain Business Council (CBBC), the Department for International Trade, the Institute of Directors and Leicestershire LEP have put together a five part programme to lead companies from an introduction to the Chinese e-commerce market through to active trading in the market.

The first stage will be this half day introductory masterclass which will outline the opportunities and challenges of selling in the Chinese e-commerce market, and aims to equip businesses with the understanding to decide whether this opportunity is right for them, and the commitments required to be successful.

Attendees will learn about:

  •        Market background and information
  •        How Chinese e-commerce differs from that in Europe and North America
  •        Experience of a UK business trading on e-commerce sites in China
  •        The importance of social media and digital marketing
  •        What steps you need to take to prepare and protect your business in advance of trading in China
  •        Be invited to the rest of the five-part programme leading to active trading in China

name: Lean Innovation Sandpits

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit (brainstorming session) at the University of Leicester offers a confidential forum in which established business owners/directors can speak frankly, discuss issues and aspirations with around 4-5 specialists, including academics and innovation support providers, who are open, innovative and experts in their field. Their only agenda is to support local businesses to benefit from their combined expertise and experience through innovation.

During this free 2 hour LEAN Innovation Sandpit, you will be able to discuss any aspect of your business. During the Sandpit brainstorming session you will have a chance to review your business strategy, discuss issues and challenges, identify new solutions and funding sources, as well as connect with key academics in the University of Leicester and establish new collaborations.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit is open to established businesses that have a minimum turnover of £5m and are interested in growing their business through research and innovation.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit will be delivered at the Leicester Innovation Hub, part funded by European Regional Development Fund. The Leicester Innovation Hub provides innovation support and incubation support and facilities to businesses and entrepreneurs to make it easier to access the breadth of research and innovation expertise across the University of Leicester by providing dedicated practical innovation support to help companies reach business objectives.

There are three sessions available for booking – please get in touch with Leicinnovation@le.ac.uk if these times are not convenient and we will run planned  additional session for your business as needed .   

Further Information & FAQs:

What is a Lean Research and Innovation Sandpit?

LEAN Innovation Sandpit is an intensive discussion forum where free thinking is encouraged, under confidentiality, to delve into the business challenges and issues to uncover innovative solutions. Each sandpit is led by a director of the *Tiger Team that helps to outline the problem and facilitates discussions. The process is broken down into:

• Defining the scope of the issue

• Sharing an understanding of the problem

• Using creative and innovative thinking techniques to focus on a problem

• Potentially turning Sandpit outputs into a project to be supported by a Tiger Team

 

How does the *Tiger Team support the Sandpit?

After the Sandpit session, the company has the opportunity to request a *Tiger Team to be formed to progress one or more of the solutions identified collectively over a period of time. The Tiger Team is made up of highly skilled, hand-picked groups of people who are tenacious about problem solving through research and innovation.

The Leicester Innovation Hub team ensures that the Tiger Team are highly multidisciplinary mix of participants, some active researchers and others potential users of research outcomes, to drive lateral thinking and radical approaches to address innovation and research challenges. LEAN Innovation Tiger Teams at University of Leicester deliver an interactive 2-3 hour sessions involving 5-6 discipline academic experts and business innovation support providers and one SME director (and other key personnel within the business). They are a high-functioning team of specialists who come together to complete a specific project.

Participants must have the ability to collaborate, share ideas openly and solve problems together so they maximize the combined power of their skills. Tiger Teams work best for companies that are interested in open innovation by bringing together people who would not normally interact to inspire creative thinking to address business needs to help create business impact and value for all involved.

 

What are the main benefits of the Sandpits?

The benefits of the ‘sandpits’ are many and varied. It brings opportunities for knowledge sharing and generating ideas. Perhaps most excitingly these events can identify areas where a business and the University can work together on a business challenge. These sessions have been organised to provide an opportunity for businesses to take part in and become familiar with a ‘sandpit’ event as a forum, where you can share some of your business challenges, experiences and ideas with some ‘great minds’. The University, in turn, can tell you about their experiences, not only in academic circles but also in the real world.

You will be encouraged to challenge what has gone before; working across academic boundaries to discover solutions in the world of emerging social, economic and political change and challenges. Using their knowledge, skills and contacts, our experts are well placed to help support you in growing your business through research funding and innovation.

name: Good Deeds Are Good Business - Social Value
html_description:
We always used to think of neighbourhoods and localities as customer communities – you shop at your local greengrocer, butcher, hardware store and maybe go into town to buy clothes, furniture etc.

Now you have to fight for your place in the local market, competing with the internet giants and out-of-town retail parks. Customer communities are virtual and often created using complex tech solutions, empowering customers with the right to review their products and providing a tailored and personal buying experience as well as a rock bottom price.

So how can you find your place in this market?

We know that one thing hasn’t changed: good deeds make for good business. Trust remains as important as ever when you’re spending your hard-earned cash and your business’s values make a difference.

Local charities and community organisations are struggling more than ever to fund their good deeds. So how can you help them with minimal investment, raising your organisation's profile along the way?

The Public Services (Social Value) Act came into force on 31 January 2013. Leicester Ageing Together is currently running a pilot, in conjunction with the City Council, using the Social Value received from City Council contracts. Hear the how’s, why’s and wherefores and how you can use Social Responsibility and your Social Value offer to grow your business.

name: Lean Innovation Sandpits
html_description:
The LEAN Innovation Sandpit (brainstorming session) at the University of Leicester offers a confidential forum in which established business owners/directors can speak frankly, discuss issues and aspirations with around 4-5 specialists, including academics and innovation support providers, who are open, innovative and experts in their field. Their only agenda is to support local businesses to benefit from their combined expertise and experience through innovation.

During this free 2 hour LEAN Innovation Sandpit, you will be able to discuss any aspect of your business. During the Sandpit brainstorming session you will have a chance to review your business strategy, discuss issues and challenges, identify new solutions and funding sources, as well as connect with key academics in the University of Leicester and establish new collaborations.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit is open to established businesses that have a minimum turnover of £5m and are interested in growing their business through research and innovation.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit will be delivered at the Leicester Innovation Hub, part funded by European Regional Development Fund. The Leicester Innovation Hub provides innovation support and incubation support and facilities to businesses and entrepreneurs to make it easier to access the breadth of research and innovation expertise across the University of Leicester by providing dedicated practical innovation support to help companies reach business objectives.

There are three sessions available for booking – please get in touch with Leicinnovation@le.ac.uk if these times are not convenient and we will run planned  additional session for your business as needed .   

Further Information & FAQs:

What is a Lean Research and Innovation Sandpit?

LEAN Innovation Sandpit is an intensive discussion forum where free thinking is encouraged, under confidentiality, to delve into the business challenges and issues to uncover innovative solutions. Each sandpit is led by a director of the *Tiger Team that helps to outline the problem and facilitates discussions. The process is broken down into:

• Defining the scope of the issue

• Sharing an understanding of the problem

• Using creative and innovative thinking techniques to focus on a problem

• Potentially turning Sandpit outputs into a project to be supported by a Tiger Team

 

How does the *Tiger Team support the Sandpit?

After the Sandpit session, the company has the opportunity to request a *Tiger Team to be formed to progress one or more of the solutions identified collectively over a period of time. The Tiger Team is made up of highly skilled, hand-picked groups of people who are tenacious about problem solving through research and innovation.

The Leicester Innovation Hub team ensures that the Tiger Team are highly multidisciplinary mix of participants, some active researchers and others potential users of research outcomes, to drive lateral thinking and radical approaches to address innovation and research challenges. LEAN Innovation Tiger Teams at University of Leicester deliver an interactive 2-3 hour sessions involving 5-6 discipline academic experts and business innovation support providers and one SME director (and other key personnel within the business). They are a high-functioning team of specialists who come together to complete a specific project.

Participants must have the ability to collaborate, share ideas openly and solve problems together so they maximize the combined power of their skills. Tiger Teams work best for companies that are interested in open innovation by bringing together people who would not normally interact to inspire creative thinking to address business needs to help create business impact and value for all involved.

 

What are the main benefits of the Sandpits?

The benefits of the ‘sandpits’ are many and varied. It brings opportunities for knowledge sharing and generating ideas. Perhaps most excitingly these events can identify areas where a business and the University can work together on a business challenge. These sessions have been organised to provide an opportunity for businesses to take part in and become familiar with a ‘sandpit’ event as a forum, where you can share some of your business challenges, experiences and ideas with some ‘great minds’. The University, in turn, can tell you about their experiences, not only in academic circles but also in the real world.

You will be encouraged to challenge what has gone before; working across academic boundaries to discover solutions in the world of emerging social, economic and political change and challenges. Using their knowledge, skills and contacts, our experts are well placed to help support you in growing your business through research funding and innovation.

name: Nudge for Good: Harnessing Behavioural Science to Inform Business, Charity & Policy
html_description:
Behavioural science provides a powerful way to deepen our understanding of the drivers of human behaviour. In doing so it provides simple, cost-effective ways to change behaviour in desirable ways. The focus will be on providing practical tools and methods that you can use. We shall also discuss a range of examples of behaviour change in action.

Speakers include; Professor Edward Cartwright, who is an expert in behavioural economics and Director of the Institute for Applied Economics and Social Value; Anna Cartwright, who is an Associate Professor in Economics at Coventry University and will talk about a project with the Home Office applying behaviour change in cyber-security; Charlotte Brown, who is a consultant for The Behavioural Architects, a global insight, research and consultancy business.

This event will be of interest to business, public policy and the third sector. Behavioural science provides simple and effective ways to think through problems from a different perspective. This event will equip you with the practical tools needed to apply behavioural science and instigate change.

name: Wellbeing @ Work: For Happy, Healthy, Productive Employees
html_description:
With many organisations across Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland facing difficulties with absenteeism and employee health and wellbeing, workplace health has become a high priority for many.

Benefits to organisations who invest in health and wellbeing initiatives to support staff include increased productivity through better motivated employees, greater job satisfaction and team morale, fewer sickness related costs, and a positive reputation for your company, leading to staff retention and recruitment.

This free workshop will give you a background to the current picture of health and wellbeing in our local workplaces and provide advice / guidance for engaging with employees and implementing health and wellbeing initiatives to support staff to improve their health.

You will be provided with an overview of the vision for improving the health of local workplaces, and the facts and figures for absenteeism, presenteeism and the incidence of poor physical and mental health amongst our workers. We will outline the Leicestershire and Rutland Sport (LRS) Wellbeing @Work support package, which includes a FREE* Workplace Health Needs Assessment (developed by Public Health England and Healthy Working Futures, 2017) to support business to gauge the wellbeing status of their employees. (Eligibility criteria applies).

In addition, we will also be sharing good practice from those organisations who have accessed the Wellbeing @Work package in the last 12 months, and how the support provided has added value to the health of their workplace. They will share how the insight they have gained from the Workplace Health Needs Assessment has guided them in their strategy and action plan development to ensure that health and wellbeing interventions are targeted and evidence-based.

The event will also include a small marketplace expo following the main talk where businesses can meet a range of local health providers specialising in various areas of health and wellbeing and can find out how as a business they can access their local services.

The workshop will end with an opportunity to ‘netwalk’ with fellow delegates and make a pledge to improve your organisations health and wellbeing.

The event is aimed at HR professionals, general managers, health and safety officers, or voluntary workplace health champions – anyone with a remit for employee health and wellbeing and who is looking for support to implement a health and wellbeing action plan or intervention is encouraged to attend.

The LRS Wellbeing @Work package is available to all businesses of any size and type, and from any sector. We will be sharing good practice from both the private and public sector. Elements of the Wellbeing @Work package are free to eligible* Leicestershire businesses.

name: A Taste of 'Fierce Conversations'
html_description:

Turnover costs associated with replacing a highly trained employee can set a company back as much as 2 times that individual’s annual salary.  

Can your business afford these costs? Probably not, but there is a way to combat ‘conversational chaos’.  

What gets talked about, who is invited, and how it gets talked about, determines what will, or won’t, happen in organisations. Having the right conversation - at the right time, with the right people, in the right way, will yield results time after time. 

This ‘Fierce Conversations’ taster session will help you develop insights to transform the conversations central to your success. ‘Fierce Conversations’ can help to: 

* maximise innovation 

* ensure your employees are empowered and working at the peak of their capability 

* reduce conflict 

* solve problems quickly 

* enhance your capacity to manage change. 

Team meetings and 1to1s will never be the same again!

This 'Fierce Conversations' taster is for leaders and business owners who want empowered and high-performing workplaces, where people and results matter equally. If I asked you: 'what's the most important thing we need to be talking about today?' and 'is this the best use of you in the organisation?' would you be happy with your answers? If you know that there are areas of your organisation and working habits you'd like to change, this is for you!

name: How to Create Effective Customer-Centric Marketing Plans
html_description:
Have you noticed that you’re constantly saying/thinking/hearing ‘We should be doing X, Y and Z in our marketing’ yet never get around to it or feel that EVERYTHING feels urgent and important? Do you struggle to plan out your marketing for the year or design website pages and user journeys that engage and convert?

These could be signs that it’s time to get back to basics and really understand your customer then design your marketing materials with them in mind. There can be a constant pull to be doing the ‘hot new thing’ and to feel pulled in a million directions at once. We’ve found that this process is a lot easier, in fact almost effortless when you’re crystal clear on what drives your customers.

In this interactive workshop we’ll take you through the process of grouping and defining your different customer groups into ‘personas’. Persona development is the first step in developing a marketing strategy that supports your business goals and returns a positive return on investment for your marketing spend.

In this workshop, we will work through the process of building up to 6 personas to be further refined and agreed with your team, then prioritise with the intention of building them into a marketing plan. We’ll help you understand the steps you’ll need to take to form into a marketing plan that is built around your customers to yield results.

Attendees will leave with a clearer understanding of their customers and where best to focus marketing efforts. The resulting documentation can be returned to again and again – to build a marketing plan, deciding which channels to focus attention on, writing messages on marketing materials, deciding which campaigns to run, briefing marketing creatives and more.

The experience your brand offers is the new competitive advantage. Your brand experience can make you memorable, noticeable and create loyalty, so why is this overlooked by so many companies?

Craig has worked with some of the world's most admired brands, such as John Lewis, Mercedes and LV= to shape their Customer Strategy, before creating Beyond Brand to service the mid-market businesses who share the same challenges.

name: Lean Innovation Sandpits
html_description:
The LEAN Innovation Sandpit (brainstorming session) at the University of Leicester offers a confidential forum in which established business owners/directors can speak frankly, discuss issues and aspirations with around 4-5 specialists, including academics and innovation support providers, who are open, innovative and experts in their field. Their only agenda is to support local businesses to benefit from their combined expertise and experience through innovation.

During this free 2 hour LEAN Innovation Sandpit, you will be able to discuss any aspect of your business. During the Sandpit brainstorming session you will have a chance to review your business strategy, discuss issues and challenges, identify new solutions and funding sources, as well as connect with key academics in the University of Leicester and establish new collaborations.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit is open to established businesses that have a minimum turnover of £5m and are interested in growing their business through research and innovation.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit will be delivered at the Leicester Innovation Hub, part funded by European Regional Development Fund. The Leicester Innovation Hub provides innovation support and incubation support and facilities to businesses and entrepreneurs to make it easier to access the breadth of research and innovation expertise across the University of Leicester by providing dedicated practical innovation support to help companies reach business objectives.

There are three sessions available for booking – please get in touch with Leicinnovation@le.ac.uk if these times are not convenient and we will run planned  additional session for your business as needed .   

Further Information & FAQs:

What is a Lean Research and Innovation Sandpit?

LEAN Innovation Sandpit is an intensive discussion forum where free thinking is encouraged, under confidentiality, to delve into the business challenges and issues to uncover innovative solutions. Each sandpit is led by a director of the *Tiger Team that helps to outline the problem and facilitates discussions. The process is broken down into:

• Defining the scope of the issue

• Sharing an understanding of the problem

• Using creative and innovative thinking techniques to focus on a problem

• Potentially turning Sandpit outputs into a project to be supported by a Tiger Team

 

How does the *Tiger Team support the Sandpit?

After the Sandpit session, the company has the opportunity to request a *Tiger Team to be formed to progress one or more of the solutions identified collectively over a period of time. The Tiger Team is made up of highly skilled, hand-picked groups of people who are tenacious about problem solving through research and innovation.

The Leicester Innovation Hub team ensures that the Tiger Team are highly multidisciplinary mix of participants, some active researchers and others potential users of research outcomes, to drive lateral thinking and radical approaches to address innovation and research challenges. LEAN Innovation Tiger Teams at University of Leicester deliver an interactive 2-3 hour sessions involving 5-6 discipline academic experts and business innovation support providers and one SME director (and other key personnel within the business). They are a high-functioning team of specialists who come together to complete a specific project.

Participants must have the ability to collaborate, share ideas openly and solve problems together so they maximize the combined power of their skills. Tiger Teams work best for companies that are interested in open innovation by bringing together people who would not normally interact to inspire creative thinking to address business needs to help create business impact and value for all involved.

 

What are the main benefits of the Sandpits?

The benefits of the ‘sandpits’ are many and varied. It brings opportunities for knowledge sharing and generating ideas. Perhaps most excitingly these events can identify areas where a business and the University can work together on a business challenge. These sessions have been organised to provide an opportunity for businesses to take part in and become familiar with a ‘sandpit’ event as a forum, where you can share some of your business challenges, experiences and ideas with some ‘great minds’. The University, in turn, can tell you about their experiences, not only in academic circles but also in the real world.

You will be encouraged to challenge what has gone before; working across academic boundaries to discover solutions in the world of emerging social, economic and political change and challenges. Using their knowledge, skills and contacts, our experts are well placed to help support you in growing your business through research funding and innovation.
